channel.title: Stefan Otte - science of no data - Stefan Otte

item.title: "Practical PyTorch" Talk at Reinforce Conf
item.description:
I gave a talk "Practical PyTorch 101" at Reinforce Conf in Budapest last March. Here is the presentation and the youtube video.

I also gave a PyTorch workshop and updated my material. Enjoy!

Thanks to the folks organizing the conference, it was a lot of fun.
item.dc:creator: Stefan Otte

item.title: Similarity Search with Neural Networks
item.description:
I gave a talk "Fun with Content-based Image Retrieval with Neural Network" at the PyData Berlin Meetup. Here are the slides as pdf. (I hope to publish the transcript of the talk in a few days.)

Thanks again to the PyData Berlin folks for organizing the event and thanks to …
item.dc:creator: Stefan Otte

item.title: "No fit?" Comparing high-level learning interfaces for PyTorch
item.description:
Note: you can find the jupyter notebook for this post here.

Update <2019-02-07>: Some corrections regarding skorch. See the update at the bottom of the page.

I really like PyTorch and I'm not alone. However, there is one aspect where PyTorch is not too user-friendly. PyTorch does not have a nice high-level fit function, i.e. a fit
item.dc:creator: Stefan Otte

item.title: PyData PyTorch Tutorial
item.description:
I attended the PyData Berlin again and it was a really good conference: great talks, great people, and well organized!

I also presented a PyTorch tutorial. You can find the material of the tutorial on github and here is the video:
item.dc:creator: Stefan Otte

item.title: Tools to ease EDA (lightning talk)
item.description: At the PyData Berlin I prepared a lightning talk about tools to ease EDA, but I didn't give the talk due to time constraints :) You can find the notebook of the talk on github.
item.dc:creator: Stefan Otte

item.title: PyData Talk 2017: On Bandits and Swipes - Gamification of Search
item.dc:creator: Stefan Otte

item.title: dplyr for python
item.description:
dplyr enlightenment with pandas¶

I tried to reach dplyr enlightenment in the pandas ecosystem, but what I found was different from what I expected. Be warned: opinions ahead!

According to the dplyr homepage

"dplyr is a grammar of data manipulation, providing a consistent set of verbs that help > you solve the most common data manipulation challenges.
item.dc:creator: Stefan Otte

item.title: Note to self: How to publish packages on PyPI
item.description: ...because I always forget which tools to use in what order and what can go wrong.
